column1:
Happiness equals reality minus expectations.

Tom Magliozzi

Now that my storehouse
has burned down, nothing
conceals the moon.

Masahide

Everything has its wonders, even darkness and silence, and I learn, whatever state I may be in, therein to be content.

Helen Keller
If a man knows not to which port he sails, no wind is favorable. (Seneca)

The unexamined life is not worth living.

Socrates
Sometimes you put walls up not to keep people out, but to see who cares enough to break them down. (Socrates)
The secret of happiness, you see, is not found in seeking more, but in developing the capacity to enjoy less. (Socrates)

In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispensable.

Dwight D. Eisenhower

He that complies against his will
Is of his own opinion still
Which he may adhere to, yet disown,
For reasons to himself best known.

Samuel Butler

Imagination is the only weapon in the war against reality.

Alice in Wonderland, The Cheshire Cat

Now the world has gone to bed / Darkness won't engulf my head
I can see by infra-red / How I hate the night

Now I lay me down to sleep / Try to count electric sheep
Sweet dream wishes you can keep / How I hate the night

The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, Marvin's Lullaby
He who laughs at himself never runs out of things to laugh at. (Epictetus)

If you want to improve, be content to be thought foolish and stupid with regard to external things.

Epictetus

Any person capable of angering you becomes your master; he can anger you only when you permit yourself to be disturbed by him.

Epictetus

Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together, but do so with all your heart.

Marcus Aurelius

Get busy with life's purpose, toss aside empty hopes, get active in your own rescue.

Marcus Aurelius

It is not death that a man should fear, but he should fear never beginning to live.

Marcus Aurelius

Never let the future disturb you. You will meet it, if you have to, with the same weapons of reason which today arm you against the present.

Marcus Aurelius

The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.

Marcus Aurelius

Whenever you are about to find fault with someone, ask yourself the following question: What fault of mine most nearly resembles the one I am about to criticize?

Marcus Aurelius
Tell me how you read and I'll tell you who you are. (Martin Heidegger)

Turning away from a flight from death, you see a horizon of opportunity that puts you in a state of anticipatory resoluteness with solicitous regard for others that makes your life seem like an adventure perfused with unshakeable joy.

Martin Heidegger

If I take death into my life, acknowledge it, and face it squarely, I will free myself from the anxiety of death and the pettiness of life -- and only then will I be free to become myself.

Martin Heidegger

All of humanity's problems stem from man's inability to sit quietly in a room alone.

Blaise Pascal

It takes something more than intelligence to act intelligently.

Fyodor Dostoyevsky

To go wrong in one's own way is better than to go right in someone else's.

Fyodor Dostoyevsky

If at least I had solved my problems! Oh, I had not settled one of them, and how many there were! But I gave up caring about anything, and all the problems disappeared.

Fyodor Dostoyevsky

Clocks slay time... time is dead as long as it is being clicked off by little wheels; only when the clock stops does time come to life.

William Faulkner, The Sound and the Fury

I have been one acquainted with the night. / I have walked out in rain -- and back in rain. / I have outwalked the furthest city light.

I have looked down the saddest city lane. / I have passed by the watchman on his beat / And dropped my eyes, unwilling to explain.

Robert Frost

If thou canst not ascend / These steps, die on that marble where thou art.
Thy flesh, near cousin to the common dust, / Will parch for lack of nutriment thy bones
Will wither in few years, and vanish so / That not the quickest eye could find a grain
Of what thou now art on that pavement cold. / The sands of thy short life are spent this hour,
And no hand in the universe can turn / Thy hourglass, if these gummed leaves be burnt / Ere thou canst mount up these immortal steps.

John Keats, The Fall of Hyperion: A Dream
